teleceptor.auth module¶

Authors: Victor Szczepanski

on_logout(username)[source]¶

Called on logout

teleceptor.auth.all_of(*conditions)[source]¶
Returns:True if all of the conditions match

By default all conditions are required, but this might still be needed if you want to use it inside of an any_of(...) condition

teleceptor.auth.any_of(*conditions)[source]¶
Returns:True if any of the conditions match
teleceptor.auth.check_auth(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

A tool that looks in config for ‘auth.require’. If found and it is not None, a login is required and the entry is evaluated as a list of conditions that the user must fulfill

teleceptor.auth.check_credentials(username, password, session)[source]¶

Verifies credentials for username and password. :returns: None on success or a string describing the error on failure

teleceptor.auth.member_of(groupname)[source]¶
teleceptor.auth.name_is(reqd_username)[source]¶
teleceptor.auth.require(*conditions)[source]¶

A decorator that appends conditions to the auth.require config variable.

Conditions are callables that return True if the user fulfills the conditions they define, False otherwise

They can access the current username as cherrypy.request.login

Define those at will however suits the application.

teleceptor.elasticsearchUtils module¶

Authors: Victor Szczepanski

teleceptor.elasticsearchUtils.getReadings(ds, start, end, points=None)[source]¶

Get the readings from elastic search for datastream ds between dates start and end.

Parameters:
  • ds (int) – The datastream id
  • start (float) – The time in seconds since UNIX epoch to start the query from.
  • end (float) – The time in seconds since UNIX epoch to end the query at.

:param points:The number of points to retrieve. This affects the level of aggregation when combined with the start and end times. :type points: optional int

Note

We return data points at start and end. That is, this function is inclusive of the end points.

Note

If points is None, we use the default aggregation of 1 minute.

Returns:list[(float,float)] – pairs of the form (timestamp, value) for all data in datastream ds between dates start and end.
teleceptor.elasticsearchUtils.get_elastic(elastic_buffer, index_info=None)[source]¶

Make a query to elasticsearch with args in elastic_buffer

Parma elastic_buffer:
 The query json to provide to elastic search.
Returns:list[(float,float)] – pairs of the form (timestamp, value) for all data that matches the query in elastic_buffer

Todo

May want to pass in a list of indicies to search on

teleceptor.models module¶

Models contains what information will be stored in the database for each component of the project (such as the necessary attributes to be stored for a sensor). Not all classes will have a toDict()/to_dict() function. This module cannot be run independently as it just describes the structure of the database.

Authors: Bretton Murphy
Victor Szczepanski Jessica Greenling

coefficients: str
Describes the coefficients of a polynomial function to a apply to the readings. Order of coefficients is in decreasing polynomial degree (e.g. [1, 0] represents the polynomial 1*x + 0)

class teleceptor.models.Message(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: sqlalchemy.ext.declarative.api.Base

A message contains instructions for the sensor.

id
: int
Uniquely identifies a Message.
message
: str
Instructions for the sensor to perform some action that corresponds with the sensors capabilities.
message_queue_id
: int
Used to identify a Message to a MessageQueue.
timeout
: float
The expiration time for a Message. Old messages should not be used by the sensor.
read
: bool
Indicates whether the Message as been sent to the basestation or read/acknowledged in some other way.

class teleceptor.models.MessageQueue(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: sqlalchemy.ext.declarative.api.Base

Each sensor will have it’s own unique message queue with its own identification number. The message queue can contain many messages. Message handling can be found in messages.

id
: int
Uniquely identifies the MessageQueue.
messages
: list of Message
Can be an empty list or have many elements. Used to store pending messages for sensor.
sensor_id
: str
Used to identify a MessageQueue to a Sensor.

teleceptor.timeAggregationUtils module¶

Defines high level functions for retrieving Teleceptor aggregation levels.

Authors: Victor Szczepanski

teleceptor.timeAggregationUtils.aggregation_levels = {(10801, 259200): 300, (121, 7200): 10, (0, 120): 1, (7201, 10800): 60, (259201, 9223372036854775807): 3600}¶

Defines the aggregation levels used by Teleceptor. The form is (period_start, period_end): aggregation_value. So, if some value v is between period_start and period_end, aggregation_value should be used. Does not admit negative values or values > sys.maxsize

teleceptor.timeAggregationUtils.getAggregationLevel(start, end)[source]¶

Get the appropriate aggregation level for the time period start - end.

Note

Uses the aggregation_levels dictionary for lookup. We assume the keys in aggregation_levels are non-overlapping - undefined behaviour may occur if this is not true.

Params start:The start time in seconds.
Parameters:end (int) – The end time in seconds.
Returns:int – The number of seconds to aggregate on.
teleceptor.timeAggregationUtils.getElasticSearchAggregationLevel(start, end)[source]¶

Get the appropriate aggregation level for the time period start - end, in EalsticSearch format.

This function will return the aggregation period in the lowest common division possible. For example, if the aggregation period requested is > 60 seconds but < 1 hour, this function will return the aggregation in minutes, rather than seconds or hours.

Example:
time_frame = getElasticSearchAggregationLevel(0,3 * 3600 + 1) assert(time_frame is “1m”) time_frame = getElasticSearchAggregationLevel(0,120*60 + 1) assert(time_frame is “10s”)
Params start:The start time in seconds.
Parameters:end (int) – The end time in seconds.
Returns:str – The aggregation period in ElasticSearch format, in the lowest common division.
